subject: Re: [junit] Anyway to dynamically change name of test passed  to formatter?
msgSnippet: That ought to read My suggestion.... ... J. B. Rainsberger, President, Diaspar Software Services Let s write software that people understand.
messageBody:
That ought to read "My suggestion...."

>So said J. B. Rainsberger on 2003-06-01 --------------------
>My situation is to build your test suite manually, then change your test
>case class' constructor to accept the parameters that you need to take.
>
>suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
>
> loop somehow {
> suite.addTest(new ParameterizedTestCase(param1, param2, ...));
> }
>
> return suite;
>}
>
>ParameterizedTestCase(param1, param2, ...) {
> super(makeSuiteName(param1, param2, ...));
> this.param1 = param1;
> ...
>}
>
>static String makeSuiteName(...) {
> return "ParameterizedTestCase<" + param1 + ", " + param2 + ... + ">";
>}
>
>The key points are these:
>
>* Build your test suite by looping over the set of parameters you need to
>pass.
>* Code a method to build a meaningful test case name from your parameters.
>* Code your constructor to accept all the parameters your test needs.
>* Store the parameters in the test's fixture.
>* Code your test methods normally.
>
>That should help you get on your way.
>
>>So said Thomas Porter on 2003-05-31 --------------------
>>I have a situation similar to that in recipe 4.20 of the Java Extreme
>>Programming Cookbook by O'Reilly. This is a way to run a single test with
>>a
>>single test method multiple times with different arguments being passed to
>>the
>>test method for each iteration.
>>
>>I assume that if I looked at the formater output from a test like this I
>>would
>>see the same test name / test method name repeated once for each
>iteration.
>>
>>While I have seen the API javadoc on the setName() method, I do not
>>understand
>>it, nor do I know if it would affect the formatter output. I would
>>_really_
>>like to read in the name I want for a test along with the test data (in
>>the
>>one-time test suite setup() I think), and have a way to dynamically set
>the
>>method name (or test name), so I would see a useful list of tests in the
>>formatter output. I _could_ print the testname read in with the argumens
>>to
>>Sysout, but that is so scruffy, and the versions of junit (3.8.1) and ant
>>(1.5.3) I use, do not seem to display the sysout output in the junitreport
>>html
>>pages.
>>
>>
>>Any hints or suggestions welcome!
>>--
>>Tom Porter txporter@...
